![](assets/img/lecture/John_Snow.jpg) ::: ::: ## Health Geography
::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {.color-box-light-blue .fragment} **Environmental health**: focuses on environmental hazards, environmental risk assessment, and the physical and psycho-social health impacts of environmental contamination. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {.color-box-light-blue .fragment} **Disease ecology**: study of infectious diseases and the spatial distribution of environmental, social, political & economic conditions associated with disease. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {.color-box-light-blue .fragment} **Health care delivery and access**: spatial patterns of health care provision and patient behavior. ::: ::: ::: ::: {.notes} Health geography is the application of geographical information, perspectives, and methods to the study of health, disease, and health care. Mencionar usos y aplicaciones del SR en los 3 campos ::: ## Health Geography
::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {.color-box-light-blue .fragment .fade-out} **Environmental health**: focuses on environmental hazards, environmental risk assessment, and the physical and psycho-social health impacts of environmental contamination. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {.color-box-light-magenta .fragment .grow} **Disease ecology**: study of infectious diseases and the spatial distribution of environmental, social, political & economic conditions associated with disease. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ::: {.color-box-light-blue .fragment .fade-out} **Health care delivery and access**: spatial patterns of health care provision and patient behavior. ::: ::: ::: ::: {.notes} While RS has applications in all fields, I'll focus on those related to disease ecology ::: ## Disease Ecology I ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="57%"}

![](assets/img/lecture/global_view_diseases.png){width="700"} ::: ::: {.column width="43%"} The main objective is to understand the influence of environmental factors and to predict when and where a disease is most likely to occur ::: {style="display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"} {{< fa solid angles-down size=2x >}} ::: decision making, planning of prevention, management or response actions, etc. ::: ::: ## Disease Ecology II ::: {.r-stack} ![](assets/img/lecture/disease_triad.jpg){.fragment width="150%" fig-align="center"} ![](assets/img/lecture/lambin_2010.png){.fragment width="85%" fig-align="center"} ::: ## Applications of geospatial technologies {.smaller} ::: incremental - Spatialisation of outbreaks (space-time patterns and causes) - Hosts and vector distribution mapping - Estimation of environmental indices and monitoring of favorable environmental conditions - Disease risk mapping and prediction of number of cases - Landscape analysis: metrics, fragmentation, LULCC detection - Optimal distribution of health services - Location of best routes to hospitals - etc. ::: ## What about remote sensing? ![Relationship among different RS resolutions](assets/img/lecture/all_resolutions_relation.png){fig-align="center"} ::: {.notes} What can we see with remote sensing to contribute to disease ecology? ::: ## Remote sensing & scale I
![](assets/img/lecture/scale_vs_variables_spp_distr.png) ## Remote sensing & scale II ::: {.panel-tabset} ## Taxonomy ![](assets/img/lecture/resolution_vs_animals.png) ## Plants ![](assets/img/lecture/resolution_vs_forest.png) ## Animals ![](assets/img/lecture/resolution_vs_movement_a.png){.r-stretch} ::: ## How can we use RS? I
![General approach used in disease ecology](assets/img/lecture/workflow_sdm_other.png) ## How can we use RS? II - To map the response variables, i.e., species occurrence or abundance, infections - To map the predictor variables - To validate predictions ## { background-image="assets/img/lecture/satellite_and_earth.jpg" } ::: { style="color: #ffffff" } Let's have a look at real cases ::: --- ### Detecting and mapping species occurrences - Very high resolution imagery - For plants species, also hyperspectral data ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="53%"}
![(a) Emperor penguins. (b) Elephants ](assets/img/lecture/map_spp_from_vhr_img.png) ::: ::: {.column width="47%"}
![Great gerbil burrows classification](assets/img/lecture/great_gerbil_burrows.jpg) ::: ::: --- ### Time series analysis of satellite products - MODIS LST temporal and spatial reconstruction - Detection of spatial and temporal clusters of favorable conditions for the occurrence of West Nile Fever cases in Greece ::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="33%"} ![LST gap-filling process](assets/img/lecture/fig_modis_workflow.png) ::: ::: {.column width="67%"}

![](assets/img/lecture/app-reports.png) ::: ::: --- ### Other projects underway or in the pipeline {.smaller} - Integrated surveillance system for vector-borne diseases based on spatial information (FMS, kan; BID funding). - Incidence of respiratory diseases as a function of remotely sensed air quality and LULCC (citizen science and web-based data mining) (PhD Thesis project Abraham Coiman - CONAE) - Distribution of mother-to-child transmission diseases and access to health in the triple border Argentina-Bolivia-Paraguay (Doctoral thesis project Carla Rodriguez Gonzalez - CONICET) - Comprehensive epidemiological characterisation of intestinal parasite infection in children in the Department of General José de San Martín, Salta (Doctoral thesis project Matias Scavuzzo - CONICET). - Geospatial modelling of malnutrition in children and adolescents in Argentina (Doctoral thesis project Micaela Campero - CONICET) - Environmental variables associated with non-communicable diseases (Postdoctoral fellow Juan Diego Pinotti) ## Gaps, opportunities and challenges ## Difficulties and challenges I - Compromise between different resolutions - VHR, LiDAR, UAV, Hyper-spectral (U$S) - Missing data, clouds, shadows (spatial and temporal interpolations) - Need for corrections of various types - Large volumes of data vs. bandwidth, storage and computational capacity (cloud computing, parallelisation, learning time and U$S) Field data will always be needed! :) ## Difficulties and challenges II - Updating and digitisation of disease cases and intervention data - Harmonisation of records at different levels and from different systems - Facilitating data access and public access to aggregated health data - Training of staff - Development of standardised, reproducible and scalable methods - Commitment and allocation of resources ## New missions ## UAVs ## SDGs and One Health # { background-image="assets/img/lecture/CONAE_aereo.png" } ::: {.r-fit-text style="color: <script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
